criteria: Ability to represent real-world constraints with inequalities.
Understanding and representation of inequality solutions on a number line.
Recognition of infinite solutions for inequalities.
descriptions: No attempt to represent constraints with inequalities.
Struggles to represent constraints and conditions using inequalities; representation is often inaccurate or incomplete.
Represents simple constraints with inequalities but struggles with more complex scenarios; some inaccuracies present.
Consistently represents constraints with inequalities accurately, though some minor errors may be present in complex problems.
Accurately represents a wide range of real-world constraints with appropriate inequalities, demonstrating a strong understanding.
Masterfully represents complex and nuanced real-world constraints with precise inequalities; demonstrates keen insight.
No attempt to represent solutions on a number line.
Unable to accurately represent inequality solutions on a number line; struggles with basic concepts.
Represents solutions on a number line with significant errors, such as incorrect direction or endpoint notation.
Generally represents solutions correctly on a number line, but may make minor errors with endpoint notation (open vs. closed circles).
Accurately represents solutions of inequalities on a number line, including correct endpoint notation and direction.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of inequality solutions by accurately representing them on a number line and explaining the significance of endpoint notation.
Does not recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions.
Shows limited awareness of the concept of infinite solutions; unable to articulate why inequalities have infinite solutions.
Recognizes that inequalities have multiple solutions, but does not explicitly acknowledge the concept of infinite solutions.
Acknowledges that inequalities have infinitely many solutions but struggles to explain the concept clearly.
Clearly understands and articulates that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions.
Provides a sophisticated explanation of why inequalities have infinite solutions, connecting the concept to the number line and the density of real numbers.
